author: .vbuterin
content: Well if you have a secure environment that is capable of throwing away the keys then you could just use timelock encryption

author: .vbuterin
content: The encrypt-to-VDF stuff is solving a harder problem, where there is a VDF and then some unrelated party who can't influence the VDF input has data that they want to encrypt to the output

author: sky.cactus
content: What do you mean by timelock encryption here if not what I am describing or a multisig?

author: sky.cactus
content: This is what I want.  I want to encrypt something and publish it to the world and be certain that anyone can decrypt it in the future, but no one can decrypt it today.

author: sky.cactus
content: By running in SGX and deleting the data and keys, there is a point-in-time trust of SGX, but not an ongoing trust of SGX (which greatly reduces the normal SGX risks).

author: .vbuterin
content: right, so with timelock encryption you can do that if you can convince people to solve your own VDF instance

author: .vbuterin
content: If you want everyone doing this to share a VDF instance (eg. use the ethereum one), then you can't

author: .vbuterin
content: What's the latest on VDF schemes that support encrypt-to-output?

author: sky.cactus
content: As soon as one person solves the VDF they can choose to share the result.  In my case, it can be assumed that sharing the result is desired by almost everyone, so there isn't a worry that people will keep the results to themselves.

author: sky.cactus
content: Or are you saying that you can only decrypt by solving the entire VDF yourself, you can't "share the decryption key" later or prove that the result you present is the encrypted data?
